newsitem.title: BANGLADESH: Former PM Khaleda wants early poll in Bangladesh.
newsitem.headline: Former PM Khaleda wants early poll in Bangladesh.

text.p: Bangladesh opposition leader Begum Khaleda Zia on Tuesday said she would launch a movement to agitate for mid-term polls to end what she called the current government's pattern of misrule.
"The people no longer want the government to fulfil it's five year-term. It may be necessary to call mid-term elections," she told members of the Overseas Correspondent Association of Bangladesh.
Khaleda said the country's economic condition had worsened and law and order deteriorated under the government of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina.
Khaleda's Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP) lost to Hasina's Awami League in June 1996 general elections supervised by a neutral caretaker government.
She said unemployment was rife, inflation soaring, exports were falling and capital markets in shambles.
"Banks are faced with a chronic liquidity crisis. Domestic entrepreneurs are starving from a credit crunch," she said.

The government has said it was determined to raise the country's economic growth to an average of seven percent annually over the next five years. A draft five-year government plan (1997-2002) aims to spur employment and reduce the number of Bangladeshis below the poverty line to 30 percent from 45 percent now.
"We will force an early election through a movement. This government has failed to run the country," Khaleda said.
She said nearly 200 members of her party were killed by the "goons of the ruling party" and thousands more languished in prison on false charges. The government has denied such accusations.
"We are discussing with other political parties for a united movement against the government," she said.

The Awami League has 178 of the parliament's 330 seats while the BNP holds 113. Former president Hossain Mohammad Ershad's Jatiya Party has 33, and the Islamic fundamentalist Jamaat-e-Islami occupies three.
Khaleda is seeking an alliance with Jamaat and other small Islamic and right-wing parties that split the remaining seats.
"We wanted to cooperate with the government. But how could we do that? It (the government) is harassing our party workers. The government must correct itself immediately," she said.
"(But) we are helping the government by not taking any harsh actions like frequent strikes as yet."
Khaleda also blasted the government's relations with neighbouring India, particularly India's desire for transit rights through Bangladesh to more easily reach its seven remote northeastern states.
"This will have serious implications on our national security," she said.
Bangladesh's opposition parties say India actually wants the ability to transport troops and arms to suppress the "freedom struggle" in those states, where a number of insurgent groups seek autonomy.
But she also accused India of "sheltering Shanti Bahini insurgents that carry out barbarous attacks on our people from across the border," she said.

The tribal rebels in Bangladesh's southeastern Chittagong Hill Tracts area, called Shanti Bahini (peace force), have been fighting a decades-old bush war for autonomy for their rugged 5,500 sq-mile (14,200 sq-km) region.
